docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a wife-and-husband team of independent scholars, we were heartened that you have come to acknowledge the important role unaffiliated scholars play in intellectual life (Arts & Ideas pages, May 8). We were troubled, however, that most of the scholars you profiled were either married to employed people or supported themselves with another job.
docs.abstract: Letter from Sheila Blair and Jonathan Bloom, husband-and-wife team of independent scholars, lauds May 8 article acknowleging important role that unaffiliated scholars play in intellectual life; cites some of bread-and-butter issues that are big problems for independent scholars, like finding affordable health-care insurance and preparing for retirement without a pension

docs.lead_paragraph: KRONMAN-Carol J., Esq.. Of NYC, NY, on May 8, 1999. Mother of Audrey Boughton and Heather Lipkind. Daughter of Robert and Helen Kronman. Sister of Dr. Barry Kronman. A memorial service will be held on Friday, May 14, at 9:30AM in the Rockefeller Chapel of Hope and Remembrance at the Health Care Chaplaincy, 307 E. 60th St., NYC, NY (212) 644-1111. KRONMAN-Carol J. The Yeshiva University family mourns the untimely passing of a dear friend, an eminent attorney and publisher in the fields of real estate and insurance. Devoted alumna of our Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, she was a dedicated Board member of our Stern College for Women. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children, Audrey (and Jeffrey) Boughton and Heather Lipkind Kronman; parents, Robert and Helen Kronman; brother, Dr. Barry Kronman; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Lea Eisenberg, Chairman SCW Board of Direct KRONMAN-Carol J., Esq. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of American ORT deeply mourn the passing of its long-time, generous supporter and friend, who served as a member of our national Board for many years, and received the Service Award from the Real Estate and Construction Industry Chapter of American ORT. Her dedication to the Jewish people, children and education is her legacy to the students of ORT. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her two daughters Audrey and Heather, her parents, Robert and Helen Kronman, and brother, Barry. Michael R. Stoler, Pres. Brian J. Strum, Exec V.P.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cafeteria workers are waging a small but spirited drive for union recognition for 200 employees of a company that provides food service at two of New York's symbols of opulence: Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Metropolitan Opera. Most of the contractor's workers at Goldman, Sachs and the Met have signed cards saying they want to join the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union. But the company, Restaurant Associates, has declined to recognize their union and is instead insisting on an election supervised by the National Labor Relations Board.

headline.main: Cafeteria Workers Seek Union at Goldman, Sachs and Metropolitan Opera

docs.abstract: Cafeteria workers employed by Restaurant Associates, company that provides food service at Goldman Sachs & Co and Metropolitan Opera, are waging campaign to join Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union; Restaurant Associates has declined to recognize their union and is insisting instead on election supervised by National Labor Relations Board (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When President Nelson Mandela's governing African National Congress issued a 14-page booklet on ''moral renewal'' last week, South Africa's opposition parties barely paused for breath before labeling it ''insulting insincerity.'' Enough with the ''pious speech,'' the ''fruitless workshops'' and the ''glossy booklets,'' said the opposition United Democratic Party.

headline.main: South Africans Mock an Anti-Corruption Effort

docs.abstract: Corruption is emerging as key political issue in South Africa's second post-apartheid elections; majority of South Africans give Pres Nelson Mandela's governing African National Congress poor rating in rooting out and controlling corruption within its ranks, many deriding its efforts as insulting and insincere; ANC has lately begun to take on issue; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City's largest union of municipal workers has accused a city contractor of engaging in crude anti-labor tactics when it dismissed six computer workers who were vocal supporters of a unionization drive. Officials with District Council 37, the umbrella group representing 120,000 city workers, said the contractor dismissed the six workers nine days ago to intimidate a newly organized group in the union just as it was setting out to negotiate its first agreement with the contractor.

headline.main: City Union Protests Ouster of Workers

docs.abstract: Officials of District Council 37, New York City's largest union of municipal workers, accuses city contractor LFI Pyramid Consulting of engaging in crude anti-labor tactics when it dismissed six computer workers who were vocal supporters of unionization drive (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Prescription drugs were not a major issue when Medicare was created in 1965, and thus never included as a benefit. But 34 years later, medicine has been transformed by new drugs to treat the ills of old age, from osteoporosis to heart disease, and many of the elderly are struggling to pay the bill. The issue has great and growing power at the grass-roots level, politicians and health care advocates say, and with the goad of an election just over the horizon, lawmakers in both parties on Capitol Hill are suddenly working on a variety of proposals to do something about it. The debate will be fully joined in a matter of weeks when the Clinton Administration produces its plan to overhaul Medicare, which is expected to propose a major new drug benefit.

headline.main: DRAWING UP PLANS TO PAY FOR PILLS FOR THE ELDERLY

docs.abstract: Issue of Medicare coverage of prescription drugs is having great political power at grass roots because many of elderly are struggling to pay their drug bills; lawmakers in Congress are suddenly working on variety of proposals to do something about problem as 2000 elections approach; debate will be fully joined within weeks when Clinton Administration produces plan to overhaul Medicare, a plan that is expected to propose major new drug benefit; agreement on any new legislation will be difficult, not simply because of partisan politics but because many politicians feel expansion of benefits must be tied to broader restructuring of program, which already has problems paying for benefits over long term; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Prescription drugs were not a major issue when Medicare was created in 1965, and thus never included as a benefit. But 34 years later, medicine has been transformed by new drugs to treat the ills of old age, from osteoporosis to heart disease, and...

docs.lead_paragraph: RECALLING the opening of Bloomingdale's in New Rochelle more than 50 years ago, Robert J. Streger, president of the New Rochelle Chamber of Commerce, said: ''It was a big event. My mother and her friends were thrilled. Bloomingdale's had come to Westchester. Now they wouldn't have to go to the city to shop anymore.'' Mr. Streger, head of Israel Streger, an insurance company founded by his father, continued: ''Bloomingdale's took over the very old Ware's Department Store on Main Street. The store was instantly a big draw and the magnet that drew people to New Rochelle. Main Street blossomed. Stores and restaurants thrived. It was a terrific time for the city, but in 1975 Bloomingdale's built a large, very modern store in White Plains, and in 1976, the New Rochelle store was closed, and Main Street slipped into a decline.''

headline.main: A Face Lift for Bloomingdale's in White Plains

docs.lead_paragraph: TWINS, these days, seem to be everywhere. Although septuplets and octuplets have attracted national attention lately, statistics show that twin births are up 47 percent nationwide from 1980 to 1996. High-order multiples (triplets or more) are extremely rare. In most multiple births, the babies come in twos, but, even then, carrying them to term isn't always easy.

headline.main: Hands, and Hearts, Filled With Twins

docs.lead_paragraph: Janine Goumbala and Kristopher Daniel had never waded in a stream before last summer. As they looked at the fish swimming next to their feet, they asked: ''We can do this? We're not going to get arrested?'' The two children, who live in the Bronx, were able to come foot to fin with the fish in a New Jersey stream because of the Fresh Air Fund, a not-for-profit organization that has provided vacations outside the city for 1.6 million low-income children since 1877.

headline.main: COMMUNITY: The Fresh Air Fund; Five Acres And Family Transform A Summer

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-13 NATO Mistook Embassy As Belgrade Arms Agency A NATO aircraft bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade because the military command mistakenly believed it was a Serbian weapons agency, NATO officials said. It was not clear who was responsible for the mistake. Officials said the Central Intelligence Agency had picked the target. It is possible that the target was picked using an outdated map of Belgrade, a NATO official said. 1
